title: Benjamin Netanyahu Facing Uphill Battle After Israel Vote
text:
TEL AVIV—Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to press ahead with forming a government a day after he appeared to fall short of a parliamentary majority and a party led by his rival edged ahead in votes.

Mr. Netanyahu woke up to a dramatically different political landscape after Tuesday’s election, with few secure options for remaining in power and potentially weeks of political uncertainty at a time of a deepening confrontation between the U.S. and Iran in the Middle East.

On Wednesday evening, Mr. Netanyahu said he maintained the backing of three right-wing and religious parties to form the next government, putting him about six seats short of a parliamentary majority in the 120-seat Knesset.

His rival, former military chief Benny Gantz, also doesn’t appear to have a majority, though he was projected by Israeli television broadcasters to have a slight edge over Mr. Netanyahu’s bloc, thanks to a surge in Arab voter turnout and the defection from the prime minister’s alliance of a small party, Yisrael Beiteinu, that is seeking a unity government.

As of Wednesday evening, Israel’s elections committee was still counting the votes and hadn’t released final results.

Mr. Gantz on Wednesday vowed to form a unity government with his Blue and White Party and Mr. Netanyahu’s Likud, though in the past he has said it would have to be without the Likud leader, who faces possible bribery and fraud charges. Mr. Netanyahu didn’t explicitly rule out a broad unity government but said he would only be part of a coalition that was headed by him and excluded Arab parties.

“This time more than ever before, especially with all the security and political situations that we face, it is forbidden that such a government be formed with anti-Zionist parties, with the Arab parties,” Mr. Netanyahu said.

While he appeared defiant on television, his decision to scrap a trip to the United Nations General Assembly next week, a favorite forum for the prime minister, signaled that his political luck was waning. He had planned to meet President Trump and hasn’t missed the international confab since 2010.

“Politically, we still don’t know where he’s going to end up, but he’s not in a good place,” said Reuven Hazan, a political-science professor at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

In unofficial results from Israel’s public broadcaster Channel 11, Mr. Gantz’s Blue and White party received enough votes for 32 seats in the 120-seat parliament, compared with 31 for Mr. Netanyahu’s Likud party. Mr. Gantz’s bloc of centrist, left-wing and Arab parties would get 56 seats to 55 for Mr. Netanyahu’s alliance of right-wing and religious parties.

Officials from Israel’s central election committee said the results would take longer to tally than in previous elections owing to new procedures introduced to protect against fraud and miscounts. Analysts said final results could come midday Thursday.

If those margins hold as votes continued to be counted Wednesday, Mr. Gantz, a former general who formed a new political party to dethrone Mr. Netanyahu, could be the first to get a chance to form a coalition government.

“We wish for the people of Israel a good and satisfactory unity government,” Mr. Gantz told reporters this morning as he left his home in Rosh Haayin.

The results appeared to make both men dependent on Yisrael Beiteinu chief Avigdor Lieberman, who isn’t committed to either side and campaigned for a unity government combining his party, Blue and White and Likud. Mr. Lieberman declined to join Mr. Netanyahu’s coalition after an election earlier this year, complaining about the prime minister’s reliance on religious parties to stay in power and prompting Mr. Netanyahu to call for a second vote.

The gambit appeared to have backfired for Mr. Netanyahu and to have rewarded Mr. Lieberman, who is now Israel’s kingmaker. President Reuven Rivlin will decide in the next few days whether Mr. Gantz or Mr. Netanyahu will get the first chance to form a coalition, after talking to Mr. Lieberman and leaders of other parties.

The early results reflected voters’ growing frustration with Mr. Netanyahu. The prime minister appeared to lose a key part of his base: secular, right-wing voters who were tired of his dependence on Israel’s ultra-Orthodox parties. And he appeared to have galvanized Israel’s Arab citizens, who turned out in higher numbers for a unified group of Arab parties that mobilized voters around what they said were Mr. Netanyahu’s efforts to intimidate them.

The possible bribery and fraud charges that Mr. Netanyahu faces pose a serious threat to his political and personal future. The charges, which Mr. Netanyahu has dismissed as a witch hunt, relate to allegations that he tried to influence media coverage of himself and his family, along with accepting gifts from two billionaire businessmen in return for favors.

If Mr. Netanyahu can’t find a way to remain prime minister, he faces the prospect of a forced resignation if he is indicted following a pretrial hearing next month. His allies have previously floated proposals to pass a law giving him immunity from charges, but those efforts faltered last spring when he failed to form a government after winning April’s elections and called a new vote.

“He looks pretty much cornered at this point,” said Emmanuel Navon, a senior fellow at the Jerusalem-based Kohelet Policy Forum.

The uncertainty comes at a turbulent time in the Middle East, with tensions rising between Washington and Tehran as the U.S. weighs a military response after accusing Tehran of attacking Saudi oil facilities. Mr. Netanyahu has been a close ally of President Trump in his efforts to pressure Iran.

Mr. Netanyahu’s central role in Israeli politics isn’t over. His reputation for outmaneuvering political opponents and preserving his hold on power as Israel’s longest-serving prime minister earned him the nickname “the magician.”

For now, Likud officials say they are sticking with Mr. Netanyahu, giving him a large political base of support. Likud has pressured Mr. Gantz and his Blue and White party to form a unity government with Mr. Netanyahu as the head of the party.

Mr. Netanyahu could also try to persuade political parties such as Mr. Lieberman’s Yisrael Beiteinu or the Labor party to abandon their campaign promises and sit with him.

But both Mr. Lieberman and Labor seemed unwilling to do that on Wednesday, potentially looking instead to the potential for fresh leadership in Israel for the first time in a decade, with a new crop of leaders promising a less divisive politics.

—Dov Lieber contributed to this article.

Write to Felicia Schwartz at Felicia.Schwartz@wsj.com
